												A great castle building and strategy simulation.  I'm glad to see this in an HD remake for modern systems.  I just really enjoy this game a lot and it i definitely one that I keep coming back to several years after its initial publish.The game plays a lot like any other "simulation" game in that you don't have direct control over the minions you have available.  Rather, you make buildings that provide jobs for your minions.  This creates chains of industry.  For example, you spot a woodworker's hut to gather wood.  Then spot a Fletcher's workshop to create bows.  Supplement this with a cow farm/tanner's facility to provide leather armor and now your fletcher can begin making crossbows (or it could be iron...haven't played in a while!).  Strategy comes in laying out your castle defenses or siege equipment, depending on the mission.  Sighting walls, towers, and gates can provide almost god-like advantages in holding off massive sieges.  On the other side, deciding where to send your tunnelers and siege equipment while covering them with archers can open holes in the most vulnerable of positions.If you're looking for the latest graphics, or expecting something visually spectacular, pass up this game for something else.  Stronghold HD is just a resolution update for a game that came out in 2001.  Also, the AI can be downright predictable as it tends to want to assemble in the same place and wait for a while before beginning its siege phase.  This makes some missions laughably easy as you're able to set up traps in this assembly area and slaughter the AI army long before they begin to make their first moves.Altogether, though, it's a fun game.  Definitely a must-play if you're a thinking type person who likes a bare minimum of city planning.

If you scroll over buildings you'll hear the sound of work going on inside. Building walls and roofs also becomes transparent when work is going on, showing animations of workers/weapon makers (and in the case of inn's: drunkards) inside.All of the inhabitants in your castle deliver some simple dialogue when selected, reflecting what they think of the imminent situation and about you as their lord. When attacked women and children scream as they run for their homes to take cover.All of this makes the landscape and the castle come to life. Everything is littered with small details adding to the visual and audible appeal.As for gameplay there's a main military campaign with 21 separate missions, as well as a shorter Economic Campaign. In the military campaing focus lies on training units and defeating your enemy or successfully defend against enemy attack, while the economic campaign focus on gathering specific supplies.There are also stand alone missions like historically inspired sieges feauturing game renderings of real life castles.You don't control your peasants but only your military units. Peasants moves to your castle if you have housing for them and provide them with food. You'll have to balance the amount of food you hand out and your tax rate to keep people happy. If they are unhappy they will leave your castle.You can also manage your peasants by placing "good" or "bad" things. Placing ponds and gardens increase happiness and gives your soldiers bonuses in a fight, but your peasants will work slower strolling in the park now and then. Placing chopping blocks or skulls on spikes will do the opposite. It will lower happiness and give soldiers penalties in battles but increase output from your buildings.The crafting tree is pretty complicated in Stronghold. To make bread you first need a wheat farm, then a wind mill and last a bakery. All goods go through the stockpile beside your Keep/Stronghold, except bread that goes to the granary. If either the granary or the stockpile gets full they will need to be expanded or production will halt. Have this in mind when placing buildings.Weapons follow the same rules: you need wood to make bows, crossbows and spears, iron to make platemale, swords and maces, and leather to make leather armour. To get wood you need woodchoppers, to get iron you need mines and to get leather you need a farm and a tanner.Many production lines cross, and you'll have to plan what to build based on the land available (apples and wheat don't grow in any soil, and cows need to grace) and the threat you are facing. You have to protect your lord or you will be immediatly defeated, but leave your farms unprotected and they will likely all be destroyed in the event of an attack.There is also a freebuild mode where you build and manage your castle on a map of your choice without intervention. Build the castle of your dreams!A map editor is available where you can edit the terrain of your map and build castles and place buildings. Make your own scenario, stand alone mission or freebuild map.The editor is also very fun to play around in. No buildings will function in this mode but you don't need resources as everything is placed for free. You can build castles, place units from different factions and have them fight eachother.One negative aspect of the game is that the isometric view sometimes makes it hard to tell the elevation of different points on the map, and it's possible for characters to get stuck on terrain. Another problem is the path tracing. The enemy will always, immediatly find a hole in your wall but if your wall is intact they seem to attack the part closest to them. They do this even if that part is made up of 5 layers of stone wall and another section is made of fragile wooden wall.This makes it quite easy to lure the enemie through deathtraps like making them run back an forth through a maze of stone walls with archers on them. You don't have to exploit it ofcourse but it can be hard to resist :pIn conclusion, it's a solid game and I've had a hard time finding anything with the same feel as Stronghold. The HD edition makes much more playable on modern screens as you can zoom out and see almost the entire map at once. I defenitly recommend this to anyone interested in strategy games. It will run on practically any computer and offer hours of fun, and I haven't even tried the multiplayer.

												Being one of the gems of my childhood, you can imagine how surprised and excited I was to see this series pop up in the steam store. For those unfarmiliar, Stronghold is a sort of economy based midevail RTS. Esentially, you are given a set of different scenarios in which you have to use the resources in the varying enviorments you are given. Sometimes, these enviornments will help you get an advantage to your enemy - you may be located close to trees, which will allow you to get a quick start on building many essential things, such as food and weapon producing buildings. Otherwise, you may be given a disadvantage at times and being able to make do with what you have can make victory all the more satisfying. In Stronghold, you need to think carefully about how you spend your resources. On one hand, it will be important to build a barracks so you can hold a strong and ready militia to defend against your enemy's forces. On the other hand, in order to raise a decent army, you need to keep your peasants happy and in your castle. This requires keeping your grainary stocked with food, being able to have enough industrial buildings to build farms to keep peasants fed, and other mechanics. To be victorious, you have to carefully plan out your divison of resources - it is equally important to keep your peasants populous and happy and to have a strong defence to wane off enemy attacks, as one good strike can land a once prosperous land in ruins, and you very vulnerable to further attacks. All in all, I would strongly recommend Stronghold to anybody new to the RTS genre. RTS veterans would probably enjoy playing this one, too. There's nothing quite as satisfying as surviving a seige and being able to crush your enemy in a few swift blows.
